content:
If there is no resistor or load placed between the plates of a capacitor, the capacitor will not discharge on its own. The capacitor will remain charged until a circuit is connected across its plates that allows the stored charge to flow through the circuit.

When a circuit is connected across the plates of a capacitor, the stored charge is able to flow through the circuit, releasing the stored energy. The rate at which the energy is released depends on the resistance of the circuit and the magnitude of the stored charge.

If no circuit is connected across the plates of the capacitor, the stored charge will remain on the plates and the capacitor will remain charged. The capacitor will not discharge unless a circuit is connected across its plates that allows the stored charge to flow through the circuit.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.
